Journal Article•DOI•
A finite element method for surface restoration with smooth boundary conditions
[...]


Ulrich Clarenz, Udo Diewald, Gerhard Dziuk1, Martin Rumpf, R. Rusu1  - Show less +1 more•Institutions (1)
University of Freiburg1

01 May 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: A semi-implicit approach is presented which allows large time steps for the discretization of the boundary condition, two different numerical methods are introduced and applications are shown.

...read moreread less

Abstract: In surface restoration usually a damaged region of a surface has to be replaced by a surface patch which restores the region in a suitable way. In particular one aims for C1-continuity at the patch boundary. The Willmore energy is considered to measure fairness and to allow appropriate boundary conditions to ensure continuity of the normal field. The corresponding L2-gradient flow as the actual restoration process leads to a system of fourth order partial differential equations, which can also be written as a system of two coupled second order equations. As it is well known, fourth order problems require an implicit time discretization. Here a semi-implicit approach is presented which allows large time steps. For the discretization of the boundary condition, two different numerical methods are introduced. Finally, we show applications to different surface restoration problems.

Journal Article•DOI•
Heterogeneous material modeling with distance fields
[...]


Arpan Biswas1, Vadim Shapiro1, Igor Tsukanov1•Institutions (1)
University of Wisconsin-Madison1

01 Mar 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: This work proposes a universal approach to the problem of computer modeling of shapes with continuosly varying material properties satisfying prescribed material conditions on a finite collection of material features and global constraints and demonstrates that the approach can be implemented within the existing framework of solid modeling.

...read moreread less

Abstract: We propose a universal approach to the problem of computer modeling of shapes with continuosly varying material properties satisfying prescribed material conditions on a finite collection of material features and global constraints. The central notion is a parameterization of space by distances from the material features-either exactly or approximately. Functions of such distances provide a systematic and intuitive means for modeling: of desired material distributions as they arise in design, manufacturing, analysis and optimization of components with varying material properties.The proposed framework subsumes and generalizes a number of earlier proposals for heterogeneo as material modeling. It is theoretically complete in the sense that it allows representation of all material property functions. We demonstrate that the approach can be implemented within the existing framework of solid modeling and its numerous advantages, including: precise and intuitive control using explicit, analytic, differential, and integral constraints specified on the native geometry; guaranteed smoothness and analytic properties without meshing; and applicability to material features of arbitrary dimension, shape, and topology.

Exact computation of the medial axis of a polyhedron
[...]


Tim Culver, John Keyser1, Dinesh Manocha2•Institutions (2)
Texas A&M University1, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill2

01 Jan 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: An accurate algorithm to compute the internal Voronoi diagram and medial axis of a 3-D polyhedron using exact arithmetic and exact representations for accurate computation of the medial axis is presented.

...read moreread less

Abstract: We present an accurate algorithm to compute the internal Voronoi diagram and medial axis of a 3-D polyhedron. It uses exact arithmetic and exact representations for accurate computation of the medial axis. The algorithm works by recursively finding neighboring junctions along the seam curves. To speed up the computation, we have designed specialized algorithms for fast computation with algebraic curves and surfaces. These algorithms include lazy evaluation based on multivariate Sturm sequences, fast resultant computation, culling operations, and floating-point filters. The algorithm has been implemented and we highlight its performance on a number of examples.

[...]


Xuli Han1•Institutions (1)
Central South University1

01 Jul 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: Cubic trigonometric polynomial curves with a shape parameter are presented in this paper and can be close to the cubic B-spline curves or closer to the given control polygon than the cubicB-splines.

...read moreread less

Abstract: Cubic trigonometric polynomial curves with a shape parameter are presented in this paper. The trigonometric polynomial curves are C2 continuous and G3 continuous with a non-uniform knot vector. With a uniform knot vector, the trigonometric polynomial curves are C3 continuous for the shape parameter λ ≠ 1 and C5 continuous for λ = 1. With the shape parameter, the trigonometric polynomial curves can be close to the cubic B-spline curves or closer to the given control polygon than the cubic B-spline curves. The trigonometric polynomial curves also can be decreased to quadratic trigonometric polynomial curves which can represent ellipses. The trigonometric Bezier curve and trigonometric polynomial interpolation are also discussed.

Journal Article•DOI•
Geometric Hermite curves with minimum strain energy
[...]


Jun-Hai Yong1, Fuhua Cheng1•Institutions (1)
University of Kentucky1

01 Mar 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: The presented OGH and COH curves, combined with symmetry-based extension schemes, cover tangent angles of all possible cases and ensure automatic satisfaction of the tangent angle constraints for each OGH segment and, consequently, mathematical and geometric smoothness of each segment of the curve.

...read moreread less

Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to provide yet another solution to a fundamental problem in computer aided geometric design, i.e., constructing a smooth curve satisfying given endpoint (position and tangent) conditions. A new class of curves, called optimized geometric Hermite (OGH) curves, is introduced. An OGH curve is defined by optimizing the magnitudes of the endpoint tangent vectors in the Hermite interpolation process so that the strain energy of the curve is a minimum. An OGH curve is not only mathematically smooth, i.e., with minimum strain energy, but also geometrically smooth, i.e., loop-, cusp- and fold-free if the geometric smoothness conditions and the tangent direction preserving conditions on the tangent angles are satisfied. If the given tangent vectors do not satisfy the tangent angle constraints, one can use a 2-segment or a 3-segment composite optimized geometric Hermite (COH) curve to meet the requirements. Two techniques for constructing 2-segment COH curves and five techniques for constructing 3-segment COH curves are presented. These techniques ensure automatic satisfaction of the tangent angle constraints for each OGH segment and, consequently, mathematical and geometric smoothness of each segment of the curve. The presented OGH and COH curves, combined with symmetry-based extension schemes, cover tangent angles of all possible cases. The new method has been compared with the high-accuracy Hermite interpolation method by de Boor et al. and the Pythagorean-hodograph (PH) curves by Farouki et al. While the other two methods both would generate unpleasant shapes in some cases, the new method generates satisfactory shapes in all the cases.

University of Valencia1, University of Bradford2

Abstract: We present a new method of surface generation from prescribed boundaries based on the elliptic partial differential operators. In particular, we focus on the study of the so-called harmonic and biharmonic Bezier surfaces. The main result we report here is that any biharmonic Bezier surface is fully determined by the boundary control points. We compare the new method, by way of practical examples, with some related methods such as surfaces generation using discretisation masks and functional minimisations.

Journal Article•DOI•
Shape characterization of subdivision surfaces: case studies
[...]


K. Karĉiauskas, Jörg Peters1, Ulrich Reif2•Institutions (2)
University of Florida1, Technische Universität Darmstadt2

01 Jul 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: This paper characterizes shape near flat spots and points for the subdivision schemes devised by Catmull and Clark and by Loop and introduces a type of chart that can help a designer to detect early when a mesh will lead to undesirable curvature behavior.

...read moreread less

Abstract: For subdivision surfaces, it is important to characterize local shape near flat spots and points where the surface is not twice continuously differentiable. Applying general principles derived in [Computer Aided Geometric Design, doi:10.1016/j.cagd.2004.04.006, in press], this paper characterizes shape near such points for the subdivision schemes devised by Catmull and Clark and by Loop. For generic input data, both schemes fail to converge to the hyperbolic or elliptic limit shape suggested by the geometry of the input mesh: the limit shape is a function of the valence of the extraordinary point rather than the mesh geometry. We characterize the meshes for which the schemes behave as expected and indicate modifications of the schemes that prevent convergence to the wrong shape. We also introduce a type of chart that, for a specific scheme, can help a designer to detect early when a mesh will lead to undesirable curvature behavior.

An error-bounded approximate method for representing planar curves in B-splines
[...]


Hyungjun Park1•Institutions (1)
Chosun University1

01 May 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: This paper presents an error-bounded method for B-spline curve approximation to the given curve within the accuracy, which is simple in concept, provides reasonable accuracy control, and realizes efficient data reduction.

...read moreread less

Abstract: This paper addresses the problem of representing a given planar curve in B-splines, where the curve is not so restricted on its initial basis form that it does not have to be compatible with or derivable from B-splines. As B-spline curve approximation is inevitable in this representation process, major concerns are focused both on accuracy control and data reduction to pursue a B-spline curve with fewer control points while keeping the distance between the given curve and the B-spline curve smaller than a specified tolerance. The paper thus presents an error-bounded method for B-spline curve approximation to the given curve within the accuracy. The method adopts an approach of B-spline curve refitting accomplished via polygonal approximation of the given curve and B-spline curve fitting to the polygon. Hausdorff distance is used as a criterion for approximation quality. The offset envelope of a line segment plays an important role in controlling the Hausdorff distance between the line segment and its corresponding curve segment. The method is simple in concept, provides reasonable accuracy control, and realizes efficient data reduction. Some experimental results demonstrate its usefulness and quality.

Abstract: The tensors of curvature play an important role in differential geometry. In surface theory (1990), it is determined by the derivative of unit normal vectors of tangent spaces of the underlying surface. However every geometric object in computation is a discrete model. We can only approximate them. In estimating the curvature on polyhedral surfaces, how to approximate normal vectors is a crucial step. Chen and Schmitt (1992) and Taubin (1995) described two simple methods to estimate the principal curvatures. The weights they choose is related to the triangle areas. But this choice not the best. Max (1999) presented a new kind of weight to estimate the normal vector.In this paper, we will present a new set of weights from duality and gravity. We choose the centroid weights to approximate normal vectors and estimate the principle curvatures. This will lead to a better estimation than the area-weights. Our results are also comparable with Max's weights.

Abstract: This paper presents a new algorithm for fairing planar cubic B-spline curves. Target curvature plots prescribed by designers according to design intent are used to identify bad points and bad curve segments. The corresponding control points are then modified using local constrained optimization. The objective function is a weighed combination of two components, which are associated with the fairness in the sense of energy minimization and the coherence to the original design, respectively. Hence, designers have more control over the fairing process by using appropriate weights for the two components. Several numerical examples are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the algorithm.

Abstract: We provide asymptotic expansions for the fundamental forms, the Weingarten map, the principal curvatures, and the principal directions of surfaces generated by linear stationary subdivision schemes. Further, we define the central surface. The central surface is a spline ring that captures basic shape properties of the surface in the vicinity of an extraordinary vertex. Relating the shape properties to the spectrum of the subdivision matrix via the discrete Fourier transform yields conditions for the construction of high-quality subdivision schemes. In particular, the subsub-dominant eigenvalue should be triple and correspond to the Fourier blocks with indices 0, 2 and n - 2 of the subdivision matrix.

Dalian University of Technology1, Harbin Normal University2, Michigan State University3, Delaware State University4

Abstract: Recently, there have been improvements on reconstruction of smooth B-spline surfaces of arbitrary topological type, but the most important problem of smoothly stitching B-spline surface patches (the continuity problem of B-spline surface patches) in surface reconstruction has not been solved in an effective way. Therefore, the motivation of this paper is to study how to better improve and control the continuity between adjacent B-spline surfaces. In this paper, we present a local scheme of constructing convergent G^1 smooth bicubic B-spline surface patches with single interior knots over a given arbitrary quad partition of a polygonal model. Unlike previous work which only produces (non-controllable) toleranced G^1 smooth B-spline surfaces, our algorithm generates convergent G^1 smooth B-spline surfaces, which means the continuity of the B-spline surfaces tends to G^1 smoothness as the number of control points increases. The most important feature of our algorithm is, in the meaning of convergent approximation order, the ability to control the continuity of B-spline surfaces within the given tolerance and capture the geometric details presented by the given data points.

Journal Article•DOI•
Subdivision scheme tuning around extraordinary vertices
[...]


Loïc Barthe1, Leif Kobbelt1•Institutions (1)
RWTH Aachen University1

01 Jul 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: The standard method to derive and optimize subdivision rules in the vicinity of extraordinary vertices (EV) is extended, and the method is flexible enough to simultaneously optimize several subdivision rules, i.e., not only the one for the EV itself but also the rules for its direct neighbors.

...read moreread less

Abstract: In this paper we extend the standard method to derive and optimize subdivision rules in the vicinity of extraordinary vertices (EV). Starting from a given set of rules for regular control meshes, we tune the extraordinary rules (ER) such that the necessary conditions for C1 continuity are satisfied along with as many necessary C2 conditions as possible. As usually done, our approach sets up the general configuration around an EV by exploiting rotational symmetry and reformulating the subdivision rules in terms of the subdivision matrix' eigencomponents. The degrees of freedom are then successively eliminated by imposing new constraints which allows us, e.g., to improve the curvature behavior around EVs. The method is flexible enough to simultaneously optimize several subdivision rules, i.e., not only the one for the EV itself but also the rules for its direct neighbors. Moreover, it allows us to prescribe the stencils for the ERs and naturally blends them with the regular rules that are applied away from the EV. All the constraints are combined in an optimization scheme that searches in the space of feasible subdivision schemes for a candidate which satisfies some necessary conditions exactly and other conditions approximately. The relative weighting of the constraints allows us to tune the properties of the subdivision scheme according to application specific requirements. We demonstrate our method by tuning the ERs for the well-known Loop scheme and by deriving ERs for a √3-type scheme based on a 6-direction Box-spline.

Linear perturbation methods for topologically consistent representations of free-form surface intersections
[...]


Xiaowen Song1, Thomas W. Sederberg1, Jianmin Zheng1, Rida T. Farouki2, Joel Hass2  - Show less +1 more•Institutions (2)
Brigham Young University1, University of California, Davis2

01 Mar 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: By applying displacement maps to slightly perturb two free-form surfaces, one can ensure exact agreement between the images in R3 of parameter-domain approximations to their curve of intersection, which is essential to achieving topologically consistent solid model constructions through Boolean operations.

...read moreread less

Abstract: By applying displacement maps to slightly perturb two free-form surfaces, one can ensure exact agreement between the images in R3 of parameter-domain approximations to their curve of intersection. Thus, at the expense of slightly altering the surfaces in the vicinity of their intersection, a perfect matching of the surface trimming curves is guaranteed. This exact agreement of contiguous trimmed surfaces is essential to achieving topologically consistent solid model constructions through Boolean operations, and has a profound impact on the efficiency and reliability of applications such as meshing, rendering, and computing volumetric properties. Moreover, the control point perturbations require only the solution of a linear system for their determination. The basic principles of this approach to topologically consistent surface trimming curves are described, and example results from the implementation of a simple instance of the method are presented.

Abstract: Sufficient Monotone Curvature Variation (MCV) conditions for planar Bezier and B-spline curves are described in this paper. Based on the MCV conditions which are presented, a shape control method for Bezier and B-spline curves is proposed. This method is described as finding a solution of an optimization problem subject to the MCV constraints. Since the shape control method for curves retains the desirable MCV pieces and eliminates all unwanted curvature waves, designers could easily modify curves to meet their design intentions. Practical curve examples for automobile body design verify the proposed method and demonstrate its applicable potentials.

Abstract: We give a classification of subdivision refinement rules using similarity transformations of lattices. Our work expands recent results in the classification of primal triangular subdivision (Alexa, 2002). In the examples we concentrate on the cases with a low ratio of similarity and find new univariate and bivariate refinement rules with the lowest possible such ratio, showing that this very low ratio usually comes at the expense of symmetry.

...read moreread less

Journal Article•DOI•
Exploiting curvatures to compute the medial axis for domains with smooth boundary
[...]


Wendelin Degen1•Institutions (1)
University of Stuttgart1

01 Sep 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: Strong proofs of some basics facts about the medial axis transform of a planar region Ω with smooth boundary curve(s) are given and a predictor/corrector algorithm (as in the numerical analysis of ODE's) is developed.

...read moreread less

Abstract: In the paper, strong proofs of some basics facts about the medial axis transform of a planar region Ω with smooth boundary curve(s) are given. In particular the decomposition of Choi et al. (1997) is derived from the set of regular disks. Two special algorithms to compute the medial axis are presented. Due to the decomposition, they can be applied to each part of Ω separately. 
 
Emphasis is given to the local analysis of the boundary's curvatures. This leads to an interesting connection to the theory of Dupin cyclides. With this mean, a predictor/corrector algorithm (as in the numerical analysis of ODE's) is developed. The examples show that the predictor yields already an excellent approximation; so only a few refining steps of the corrector are necessary.

...read moreread less

Constructing fair curves and surfaces with a Sobolev gradient method
[...]


Robert J. Renka1•Institutions (1)
University of North Texas1

01 Feb 2004-Computer Aided Geometric Design
TL;DR: The method is described in general terms and results are presented which demonstrate its effectiveness for constructing minimum variation curves which interpolate specified control points, tangent vectors, and/or curvature vectors.

...read moreread less

Abstract: We have devised a new method for constructing discrete approximations to fair curves and surfaces by directly minimizing an arbitrarily selected fairness functional subject to geometric constraints. The nonlinear optimization problem is solved efficiently by a Sobolev gradient method. We first describe the method in general terms and then present results which demonstrate its effectiveness for constructing minimum variation curves which interpolate specified control points, tangent vectors, and/or curvature vectors.

TL;DR: This work proposes a very simple and efficient procedure for computing in a recursive way the conversion matrices which provide the direct transformation between uniform B-spline and Bezier representations of arbitrary degrees.

...read moreread less

Abstract: In computer-aided design it is both convenient and practical to use the matrix form in representing parametric curves and surfaces. One of the reasons is that the matrix notation allows an easy conversion between different shape representations and provides a convenient implementation in either hardware or software with available matrix facilities.In this work we propose a very simple and efficient procedure for computing in a recursive way the conversion matrices which provide the direct transformation between uniform B-spline and Bezier representations of arbitrary degrees.

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 May <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__a-finite-element-method-for-surface-restoration-with-smooth-2i7bez6gtr" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>A semi-implicit approach is presented which allows large time steps for the discretization of the boundary condition, two different numerical methods are introduced and applications are shown.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__a-finite-element-method-for-surface-restoration-with-smooth-2i7bez6gtr">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__a-finite-element-method-for-surface-restoration-with-smooth-2i7bez6gtr">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__a-finite-element-method-for-surface-restoration-with-smooth-2i7bez6gtr" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>In surface restoration usually a damaged region of a surface has to be replaced by a surface patch which restores the region in a suitable way. In particular one aims for C1-continuity at the patch boundary. The Willmore energy is considered to measure fairness and to allow appropriate boundary conditions to ensure continuity of the normal field. The corresponding L2-gradient flow as the actual restoration process leads to a system of fourth order partial differential equations, which can also be written as a system of two coupled second order equations. As it is well known, fourth order problems require an implicit time discretization. Here a semi-implicit approach is presented which allows large time steps. For the discretization of the boundary condition, two different numerical methods are introduced. Finally, we show applications to different surface restoration problems.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 Mar <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__heterogeneous-material-modeling-with-distance-fields-312cgslwyt" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>This work proposes a universal approach to the problem of computer modeling of shapes with continuosly varying material properties satisfying prescribed material conditions on a finite collection of material features and global constraints and demonstrates that the approach can be implemented within the existing framework of solid modeling.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__heterogeneous-material-modeling-with-distance-fields-312cgslwyt">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__heterogeneous-material-modeling-with-distance-fields-312cgslwyt">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__heterogeneous-material-modeling-with-distance-fields-312cgslwyt" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>We propose a universal approach to the problem of computer modeling of shapes with continuosly varying material properties satisfying prescribed material conditions on a finite collection of material features and global constraints. The central notion is a parameterization of space by distances from the material features-either exactly or approximately. Functions of such distances provide a systematic and intuitive means for modeling: of desired material distributions as they arise in design, manufacturing, analysis and optimization of components with varying material properties.The proposed framework subsumes and generalizes a number of earlier proposals for heterogeneo as material modeling. It is theoretically complete in the sense that it allows representation of all material property functions. We demonstrate that the approach can be implemented within the existing framework of solid modeling and its numerous advantages, including: precise and intuitive control using explicit, analytic, differential, and integral constraints specified on the native geometry; guaranteed smoothness and analytic properties without meshing; and applicability to material features of arbitrary dimension, shape, and topology.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 Jan <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__exact-computation-of-the-medial-axis-of-a-polyhedron-1isofp9yac" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>An accurate algorithm to compute the internal Voronoi diagram and medial axis of a 3-D polyhedron using exact arithmetic and exact representations for accurate computation of the medial axis is presented.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__exact-computation-of-the-medial-axis-of-a-polyhedron-1isofp9yac">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__exact-computation-of-the-medial-axis-of-a-polyhedron-1isofp9yac">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__exact-computation-of-the-medial-axis-of-a-polyhedron-1isofp9yac" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>We present an accurate algorithm to compute the internal Voronoi diagram and medial axis of a 3-D polyhedron. It uses exact arithmetic and exact representations for accurate computation of the medial axis. The algorithm works by recursively finding neighboring junctions along the seam curves. To speed up the computation, we have designed specialized algorithms for fast computation with algebraic curves and surfaces. These algorithms include lazy evaluation based on multivariate Sturm sequences, fast resultant computation, culling operations, and floating-point filters. The algorithm has been implemented and we highlight its performance on a number of examples.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_abstract" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__exact-computation-of-the-medial-axis-of-a-polyhedron-1isofp9yac">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__exact-computation-of-the-medial-axis-of-a-polyhedron-1isofp9yac">read less</label></div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 Jul <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__cubic-trigonometric-polynomial-curves-with-a-shape-parameter-igmo7wzxgc" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>Cubic trigonometric polynomial curves with a shape parameter are presented in this paper and can be close to the cubic B-spline curves or closer to the given control polygon than the cubicB-splines.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__cubic-trigonometric-polynomial-curves-with-a-shape-parameter-igmo7wzxgc">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__cubic-trigonometric-polynomial-curves-with-a-shape-parameter-igmo7wzxgc">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__cubic-trigonometric-polynomial-curves-with-a-shape-parameter-igmo7wzxgc" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>Cubic trigonometric polynomial curves with a shape parameter are presented in this paper. The trigonometric polynomial curves are C2 continuous and G3 continuous with a non-uniform knot vector. With a uniform knot vector, the trigonometric polynomial curves are C3 continuous for the shape parameter λ ≠ 1 and C5 continuous for λ = 1. With the shape parameter, the trigonometric polynomial curves can be close to the cubic B-spline curves or closer to the given control polygon than the cubic B-spline curves. The trigonometric polynomial curves also can be decreased to quadratic trigonometric polynomial curves which can represent ellipses. The trigonometric Bezier curve and trigonometric polynomial interpolation are also discussed.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 Mar <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__geometric-hermite-curves-with-minimum-strain-energy-plbm3h4r2b" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>The presented OGH and COH curves, combined with symmetry-based extension schemes, cover tangent angles of all possible cases and ensure automatic satisfaction of the tangent angle constraints for each OGH segment and, consequently, mathematical and geometric smoothness of each segment of the curve.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__geometric-hermite-curves-with-minimum-strain-energy-plbm3h4r2b">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__geometric-hermite-curves-with-minimum-strain-energy-plbm3h4r2b">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__geometric-hermite-curves-with-minimum-strain-energy-plbm3h4r2b" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>The purpose of this paper is to provide yet another solution to a fundamental problem in computer aided geometric design, i.e., constructing a smooth curve satisfying given endpoint (position and tangent) conditions. A new class of curves, called optimized geometric Hermite (OGH) curves, is introduced. An OGH curve is defined by optimizing the magnitudes of the endpoint tangent vectors in the Hermite interpolation process so that the strain energy of the curve is a minimum. An OGH curve is not only mathematically smooth, i.e., with minimum strain energy, but also geometrically smooth, i.e., loop-, cusp- and fold-free if the geometric smoothness conditions and the tangent direction preserving conditions on the tangent angles are satisfied. If the given tangent vectors do not satisfy the tangent angle constraints, one can use a 2-segment or a 3-segment composite optimized geometric Hermite (COH) curve to meet the requirements. Two techniques for constructing 2-segment COH curves and five techniques for constructing 3-segment COH curves are presented. These techniques ensure automatic satisfaction of the tangent angle constraints for each OGH segment and, consequently, mathematical and geometric smoothness of each segment of the curve. The presented OGH and COH curves, combined with symmetry-based extension schemes, cover tangent angles of all possible cases. The new method has been compared with the high-accuracy Hermite interpolation method by de Boor et al. and the Pythagorean-hodograph (PH) curves by Farouki et al. While the other two methods both would generate unpleasant shapes in some cases, the new method generates satisfactory shapes in all the cases.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_abstract" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__geometric-hermite-curves-with-minimum-strain-energy-plbm3h4r2b">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__geometric-hermite-curves-with-minimum-strain-energy-plbm3h4r2b">read less</label></div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__nuat-b-spline-curves-51u7h9bghe" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>This paper presents a new kind of splines, called non-uniform algebraic-trigonometric B-splines (NUAT B-splines), generated over the space spanned by {1, t,...,tk-3, cos t, sin t} in which k is an arbitrary integer larger than or equal to 3. We show that the NUAT B-splines share most properties of the usual polynomial B-splines. The subdivision formulae of this new kind of curves are given. The generation of tensor product surfaces by these new splines is straightforward.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__bezier-surfaces-of-minimal-area-the-dirichlet-approach-5d2guizg7l" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>The Plateau-Bezier problem consists in finding the Bezier surface with minimal area from among all Bezier surfaces with prescribed border. An approximation to the solution of the Plateau-Bezier problem is obtained by replacing the area functional with the Dirichlet functional. Some comparisons between Dirichlet extremals and Bezier surfaces obtained by the use of masks related with minimal surfaces are studied.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__on-harmonic-and-biharmonic-bezier-surfaces-26f732362a" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>A new method of surface generation from prescribed boundaries based on the elliptic partial differential operators is presented, which reports that any biharmonic Bezier surface is fully determined by the boundary control points.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__on-harmonic-and-biharmonic-bezier-surfaces-26f732362a">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__on-harmonic-and-biharmonic-bezier-surfaces-26f732362a">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__on-harmonic-and-biharmonic-bezier-surfaces-26f732362a" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>We present a new method of surface generation from prescribed boundaries based on the elliptic partial differential operators. In particular, we focus on the study of the so-called harmonic and biharmonic Bezier surfaces. The main result we report here is that any biharmonic Bezier surface is fully determined by the boundary control points. We compare the new method, by way of practical examples, with some related methods such as surfaces generation using discretisation masks and functional minimisations.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 Jul <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__shape-characterization-of-subdivision-surfaces-case-studies-3fjunz5vqn" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>This paper characterizes shape near flat spots and points for the subdivision schemes devised by Catmull and Clark and by Loop and introduces a type of chart that can help a designer to detect early when a mesh will lead to undesirable curvature behavior.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__shape-characterization-of-subdivision-surfaces-case-studies-3fjunz5vqn">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__shape-characterization-of-subdivision-surfaces-case-studies-3fjunz5vqn">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__shape-characterization-of-subdivision-surfaces-case-studies-3fjunz5vqn" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>For subdivision surfaces, it is important to characterize local shape near flat spots and points where the surface is not twice continuously differentiable. Applying general principles derived in [Computer Aided Geometric Design, doi:10.1016/j.cagd.2004.04.006, in press], this paper characterizes shape near such points for the subdivision schemes devised by Catmull and Clark and by Loop. For generic input data, both schemes fail to converge to the hyperbolic or elliptic limit shape suggested by the geometry of the input mesh: the limit shape is a function of the valence of the extraordinary point rather than the mesh geometry. We characterize the meshes for which the schemes behave as expected and indicate modifications of the schemes that prevent convergence to the wrong shape. We also introduce a type of chart that, for a specific scheme, can help a designer to detect early when a mesh will lead to undesirable curvature behavior.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 May <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__an-error-bounded-approximate-method-for-representing-planar-45hhmcb0ex" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>This paper presents an error-bounded method for B-spline curve approximation to the given curve within the accuracy, which is simple in concept, provides reasonable accuracy control, and realizes efficient data reduction.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__an-error-bounded-approximate-method-for-representing-planar-45hhmcb0ex">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__an-error-bounded-approximate-method-for-representing-planar-45hhmcb0ex">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__an-error-bounded-approximate-method-for-representing-planar-45hhmcb0ex" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>This paper addresses the problem of representing a given planar curve in B-splines, where the curve is not so restricted on its initial basis form that it does not have to be compatible with or derivable from B-splines. As B-spline curve approximation is inevitable in this representation process, major concerns are focused both on accuracy control and data reduction to pursue a B-spline curve with fewer control points while keeping the distance between the given curve and the B-spline curve smaller than a specified tolerance. The paper thus presents an error-bounded method for B-spline curve approximation to the given curve within the accuracy. The method adopts an approach of B-spline curve refitting accomplished via polygonal approximation of the given curve and B-spline curve fitting to the polygon. Hausdorff distance is used as a criterion for approximation quality. The offset envelope of a line segment plays an important role in controlling the Hausdorff distance between the line segment and its corresponding curve segment. The method is simple in concept, provides reasonable accuracy control, and realizes efficient data reduction. Some experimental results demonstrate its usefulness and quality.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__degree-elevation-and-developable-bezier-surfaces-32yzh3cs77" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>An algorithm is presented that generates developable Bezier surfaces through a Bezier curve of arbitrary degree and shape, which interpolates prescribed corners and tangent planes along the boundary rulings. <div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__constrained-polynomial-degree-reduction-in-the-l-2-norm-890yu8i7us" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>It is shown that the best constrained degree reduction of a given Bezier curve f of degree from n to m with Cα-1-continuity at the boundary in L2-norm is equivalent to the best weighted Euclidean approximation of the vector of Bernstein-Bezier (BB) coefficients of f.</div>

<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__constrained-polynomial-degree-reduction-in-the-l-2-norm-890yu8i7us">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__constrained-polynomial-degree-reduction-in-the-l-2-norm-890yu8i7us">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__constrained-polynomial-degree-reduction-in-the-l-2-norm-890yu8i7us" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>In this paper we show that the best constrained degree reduction of a given Bezier curve f of degree from n to m with Cα-1-continuity at the boundary in L2-norm is equivalent to the best weighted Euclidean approximation of the vector of Bernstein-Bezier (BB) coefficients of f from the vector of degree raised BB coefficients of polynomials of degree m with Cα-1-continuity at the boundary.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 May <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__estimating-normal-vectors-and-curvatures-by-centroid-weights-1hshlwg2r9" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>A new set of weights from duality and gravity is presented, choosing the centroid weights to approximate normal vectors and estimate the principle curvatures, which will lead to a better estimation than the area-weights.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__estimating-normal-vectors-and-curvatures-by-centroid-weights-1hshlwg2r9">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__estimating-normal-vectors-and-curvatures-by-centroid-weights-1hshlwg2r9">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__estimating-normal-vectors-and-curvatures-by-centroid-weights-1hshlwg2r9" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>The tensors of curvature play an important role in differential geometry. In surface theory (1990), it is determined by the derivative of unit normal vectors of tangent spaces of the underlying surface. However every geometric object in computation is a discrete model. We can only approximate them. In estimating the curvature on polyhedral surfaces, how to approximate normal vectors is a crucial step. Chen and Schmitt (1992) and Taubin (1995) described two simple methods to estimate the principal curvatures. The weights they choose is related to the triangle areas. But this choice not the best. Max (1999) presented a new kind of weight to estimate the normal vector.In this paper, we will present a new set of weights from duality and gravity. We choose the centroid weights to approximate normal vectors and estimate the principle curvatures. This will lead to a better estimation than the area-weights. Our results are also comparable with Max's weights.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_abstract" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__estimating-normal-vectors-and-curvatures-by-centroid-weights-1hshlwg2r9">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__estimating-normal-vectors-and-curvatures-by-centroid-weights-1hshlwg2r9">read less</label></div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 May <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__target-curvature-driven-fairing-algorithm-for-planar-cubic-b-4g60maqdwc" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>A new algorithm for fairing planar cubic B-spline curves that is associated with the fairness in the sense of energy minimization and the coherence to the original design, respectively is presented.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__target-curvature-driven-fairing-algorithm-for-planar-cubic-b-4g60maqdwc">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__target-curvature-driven-fairing-algorithm-for-planar-cubic-b-4g60maqdwc">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__target-curvature-driven-fairing-algorithm-for-planar-cubic-b-4g60maqdwc" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>This paper presents a new algorithm for fairing planar cubic B-spline curves. Target curvature plots prescribed by designers according to design intent are used to identify bad points and bad curve segments. The corresponding control points are then modified using local constrained optimization. The objective function is a weighed combination of two components, which are associated with the fairness in the sense of energy minimization and the coherence to the original design, respectively. Hence, designers have more control over the fairing process by using appropriate weights for the two components. Several numerical examples are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the algorithm.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 Jul <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__shape-characterization-of-subdivision-surfaces-basic-1ush7s512q" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>In this article, asymptotic expansions for the fundamental forms, the Weingarten map, principal curvatures, and principal directions of surfaces generated by linear stationary subdivision schemes are provided.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__shape-characterization-of-subdivision-surfaces-basic-1ush7s512q">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__shape-characterization-of-subdivision-surfaces-basic-1ush7s512q">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__shape-characterization-of-subdivision-surfaces-basic-1ush7s512q" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>We provide asymptotic expansions for the fundamental forms, the Weingarten map, the principal curvatures, and the principal directions of surfaces generated by linear stationary subdivision schemes. Further, we define the central surface. The central surface is a spline ring that captures basic shape properties of the surface in the vicinity of an extraordinary vertex. Relating the shape properties to the spectrum of the subdivision matrix via the discrete Fourier transform yields conditions for the construction of high-quality subdivision schemes. In particular, the subsub-dominant eigenvalue should be triple and correspond to the Fourier blocks with indices 0, 2 and n - 2 of the subdivision matrix.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 Nov <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__reconstruction-of-convergent-g-1-smooth-b-spline-surfaces-1szam1w51r" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>A local scheme of constructing convergent G^1 smooth bicubic B-spline surface patches with single interior knots over a given arbitrary quad partition of a polygonal model is presented.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__reconstruction-of-convergent-g-1-smooth-b-spline-surfaces-1szam1w51r">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__reconstruction-of-convergent-g-1-smooth-b-spline-surfaces-1szam1w51r">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__reconstruction-of-convergent-g-1-smooth-b-spline-surfaces-1szam1w51r" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>Recently, there have been improvements on reconstruction of smooth B-spline surfaces of arbitrary topological type, but the most important problem of smoothly stitching B-spline surface patches (the continuity problem of B-spline surface patches) in surface reconstruction has not been solved in an effective way. Therefore, the motivation of this paper is to study how to better improve and control the continuity between adjacent B-spline surfaces. In this paper, we present a local scheme of constructing convergent G^1 smooth bicubic B-spline surface patches with single interior knots over a given arbitrary quad partition of a polygonal model. Unlike previous work which only produces (non-controllable) toleranced G^1 smooth B-spline surfaces, our algorithm generates convergent G^1 smooth B-spline surfaces, which means the continuity of the B-spline surfaces tends to G^1 smoothness as the number of control points increases. The most important feature of our algorithm is, in the meaning of convergent approximation order, the ability to control the continuity of B-spline surfaces within the given tolerance and capture the geometric details presented by the given data points.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__clifford-algebra-lorentzian-geometry-and-rational-xjdtwiqa38" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>A new approach toward the rational parametrization of canal surfaces is presented, utilizing the underlying Lorentzian geometry, and the problem is reduced to simple algebraic manipulations.</div>

<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__clifford-algebra-lorentzian-geometry-and-rational-xjdtwiqa38">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__clifford-algebra-lorentzian-geometry-and-rational-xjdtwiqa38">read less</label></div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__clifford-algebra-lorentzian-geometry-and-rational-xjdtwiqa38" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>We present a new approach toward the rational parametrization of canal surfaces. According to our previous work, every canal surface with rational (respectively polynomial) spine curve and rational (respectively polynomial) radius function is a rational (respectively polynomial) Pythagorean hodograph curve in R3,1. Drawing upon this formalism and utilizing the underlying Lorentzian geometry, the problem is reduced to simple algebraic manipulations.We also illustrate how our work related to the previous work of pottmann and Peternell. Finally, we give an outline of an approach toward the rotation minimizing parametrization of canal surfaces.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiBox-root css-t4ikeq"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-h0fotu">01 Jul <a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-inherit MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-1b1tqk2" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14/2004" target="_blank">2004</a></span><span class="mx-1 my-auto break-all font-black ">-</span><a class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 MuiLink-root MuiLink-underlineHover css-mh4g2t" data-element="journal_name" href="https://typeset.io/journals/computer-aided-geometric-design-le7roi14" target="_blank">Computer Aided Geometric Design</a></div>
<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__subdivision-scheme-tuning-around-extraordinary-vertices-3zqkglj0g8" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>The standard method to derive and optimize subdivision rules in the vicinity of extraordinary vertices (EV) is extended, and the method is flexible enough to simultaneously optimize several subdivision rules, i.e., not only the one for the EV itself but also the rules for its direct neighbors.</div>
</div>
<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__subdivision-scheme-tuning-around-extraordinary-vertices-3zqkglj0g8">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__subdivision-scheme-tuning-around-extraordinary-vertices-3zqkglj0g8">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__subdivision-scheme-tuning-around-extraordinary-vertices-3zqkglj0g8" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>In this paper we extend the standard method to derive and optimize subdivision rules in the vicinity of extraordinary vertices (EV). Starting from a given set of rules for regular control meshes, we tune the extraordinary rules (ER) such that the necessary conditions for C1 continuity are satisfied along with as many necessary C2 conditions as possible. As usually done, our approach sets up the general configuration around an EV by exploiting rotational symmetry and reformulating the subdivision rules in terms of the subdivision matrix' eigencomponents. The degrees of freedom are then successively eliminated by imposing new constraints which allows us, e.g., to improve the curvature behavior around EVs. The method is flexible enough to simultaneously optimize several subdivision rules, i.e., not only the one for the EV itself but also the rules for its direct neighbors. Moreover, it allows us to prescribe the stencils for the ERs and naturally blends them with the regular rules that are applied away from the EV. All the constraints are combined in an optimization scheme that searches in the space of feasible subdivision schemes for a candidate which satisfies some necessary conditions exactly and other conditions approximately. The relative weighting of the constraints allows us to tune the properties of the subdivision scheme according to application specific requirements. We demonstrate our method by tuning the ERs for the well-known Loop scheme and by deriving ERs for a √3-type scheme based on a 6-direction Box-spline.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__linear-perturbation-methods-for-topologically-consistent-1do4f9cbez" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>By applying displacement maps to slightly perturb two free-form surfaces, one can ensure exact agreement between the images in R3 of parameter-domain approximations to their curve of intersection, which is essential to achieving topologically consistent solid model constructions through Boolean operations.</div>

<label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-more hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" data-element="read_more_tldr" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__linear-perturbation-methods-for-topologically-consistent-1do4f9cbez">...read more</label><label class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 read-less hover_pointer hover__primary css-11r1iy3" for="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__linear-perturbation-methods-for-topologically-consistent-1do4f9cbez">read less</label></div>
</div>
<div class="MuiBox-root css-1xlzx9v"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="abstract"><div class="MuiBox-root css-2z804d" htmlcontentheight="125px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__abstract__linear-perturbation-methods-for-topologically-consistent-1do4f9cbez" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">Abstract: </span>By applying displacement maps to slightly perturb two free-form surfaces, one can ensure exact agreement between the images in R3 of parameter-domain approximations to their curve of intersection. Thus, at the expense of slightly altering the surfaces in the vicinity of their intersection, a perfect matching of the surface trimming curves is guaranteed. This exact agreement of contiguous trimmed surfaces is essential to achieving topologically consistent solid model constructions through Boolean operations, and has a profound impact on the efficiency and reliability of applications such as meshing, rendering, and computing volumetric properties. Moreover, the control point perturbations require only the solution of a linear system for their determination. The basic principles of this approach to topologically consistent surface trimming curves are described, and example results from the implementation of a simple instance of the method are presented.</div>
</div>

<div class="MuiStack-root css-qjfyu5"><div class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 css-8dlpw5" data-element="tldr"><div class="MuiBox-root css-9scvoy" htmlcontentheight="50px"><input type="checkbox" class="collapse_toggle" id="collapsible_HTMLEllipsis__tldr__designing-fair-curves-using-monotone-curvature-pieces-16muf3x487" hidden=""><div class="html-content"><div class="html-container" style="white-space:pre-line"><span class="MuiTypography-root MuiTypography-body1 label">TL;DR: </span>A shape control method for curves is proposed, described as finding a solution of an optimization problem subject to the MCV constraints, which retains the desirable MCV pieces and eliminates all unwanted curvature waves.</div>
